metadata.case_name: Harnam Singh and Sadhu Singh v. State of Punjab

facts.text: Petitioners profess and practice the Sikh faith and are interested in the maintenance and management of Sikh Gurdwaras scheduled and notified under the Sikh Gurdwaras Act, 1925.
In or about 1919, there was considerable unrest amongst the Sikhs in the Punjab in respect of the management of their gurdwaras and shrines.
In 1922, an Act called the Sikh Gurdwaras and Shrines Act was passed, which did not satisfy the Sikhs.
In 1925, the principal Act (Sikh Gurdwaras Act, 1925) was passed for the better administration of certain Sikh gurdwaras and for enquiries into matters and settlement of disputes connected therewith.
On November 1, 1956, merger of the erstwhile State of Patiala and the East Punjab States Union (PEPSU) with the State of Punjab.
Sometime in February 1957, the Government of the State of Punjab appointed an advisory committee to report on extending the principal Act to the former PEPSU area.
In September 1957, the committee recommended extension of the principal Act to former PEPSU area.
On April 8, 1958, Sikh Gurdwaras Amendment Bill, 1958 introduced in Punjab Vidhan Sabha and sent to regional committees under Punjab Regional Committees Order, 1957.
Sometime in November 1958, meeting of Sikh Gurdwara Prabandhak Committee for annual election where majority by three votes in favour of a particular group against Shiromani Akali Dal.
Within one week of November 1958 election, notice given for meeting to consider amending Bill, but stayed by Judicial Commission.
In December 1958, special session of Vidhan Sabha summoned to consider amending Bill; originally no provisions like s. 148-B.
On December 27, 1958, regional committees submitted final report recommending addition of provisions becoming s. 148-B.
On December 31, 1958, Bill passed by Vidhan Sabha.
On January 3, 1959, Bill passed by Legislative Council.
On January 8, 1959, assent of Governor; became Punjab Act No. 1 of 1959 (Amending Act of 1959), came into force at once.
On February 2, 1959, present petition filed.
On February 14, 1959, election of 35 Sikhs under cl. (b) sub-s. (1) of s. 148-B completed.
Interim Gurdwara Board, Patiala constituted by Punjab Government Notification No. 18-Gurdwaras dated January 10, 1958.
Previous to Punjab Act No. 44 of 1953, s. 43 provided for 84 elected members, bead ministers, 12 nominated by Rajpramukh of PEPSU, 17 co-opted.
Punjab Act No. 44 of 1953 amended s. 43: 132 elected, head ministers of Darbar Sahib and four Takhts, 25 co-opted (at least 12 PEPSU residents).
S. 148-B added by Amending Act 1959: deems members of Interim Gurdwara Board Patiala as members of Board under s. 43; elects 35 Sikhs from extended territories.
Chapter XII-A headed 'Temporary and Transitional Provisions'; fresh election due in about a year under s. 43-A.
S. 43-A: new Board - 140 elected, head ministers, 15 co-opted.

legal_issues.text: Whether s. 148-B of the Sikh Gurdwaras Act, 1925 (added by Amending Act 1959) contravenes the fundamental right under Article 26(b) of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: S. 148-B violates Art. 26(b) right of Sikh denomination to manage its own affairs in matters of religion; right to be exercised by all Sikhs electing representatives directly.
Undue haste in passing Amending Act 1959 after election loss by particular group on Nov 16, 1958, to restore majority.
Members of Interim Board Patiala are government nominees, not representative, not subject to disqualifications in ss. 45, 46.
Electorate for 35 Sikhs under s. 148-B(2) not representative: some elected by joint constituencies (Sikhs + non-Sikhs), some government servants/influenced.

respondent_arguments.text: S. 148-B does not violate Art. 26(b); relates to administration of property under Art. 26(d), not matters of religion.
Powers of Board under ss. 125, 129 relate to property administration, ancillary matters; read s. 129 subject to s. 125.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 26(b) distinguished from 26(d): management of religious affairs absolute (subject to public order etc.), property administration 'in accordance with law'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Administration of property placed on different footing from right to manage religious affairs.

court_reasoning.text: 'Matters of religion' under Art. 26(b) means essential religious practices/beliefs; s. 148-B concerns Board constitution for property admin.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S. 148-B does not interfere with essential religious practices.

court_reasoning.text: Direct election by entire Sikh community not a matter of religion or essential practice; principal Act had nomination, co-option, designation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principle of direct election on universal suffrage not elevated to religion.

court_reasoning.text: S. 148-B temporary/transitional for PEPSU representation post-merger; method by convenience/expediency, not religion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Interim arrangement dictated by considerations of convenience.

court_reasoning.text: Interim Board members managed PEPSU gurdwaras; designation interim, no evidence of disqualifications.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No violation by deeming them members.

court_reasoning.text: Electorate all Sikhs electing Sikhs; joint electorates remote/indirect; no influence by non-Sikhs on Board.

holdings.text: S. 148-B does not contravene Art. 26(b); pertains to property administration regulable by law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between Art. 26(b) and (d); matters of religion as essential rites/practices; autonomy in deciding essentials.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sri Venkataramana Devaru v. State of Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: Matters of religion include essential practices regarded by community as part of religion.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition under Art. 32; challenge to violation of Art. 26(b); regional committees under Art. 371.

statutes_cited.name: Sikh Gurdwaras Act, 1925 (Punjab Act VIII of 1925)
statutes_cited.relevance: Impugned provision s. 148-B on Board constitution; powers/duties of Board/Committees on property/observances.

statutes_cited.name: Sikh Gurdwaras (Amendment) Act, 1959 (Punjab Act 1 of 1959)
statutes_cited.relevance: Added ss. 148-B to 148-F as temporary provisions; extended Act to PEPSU.

outcome.summary: The petition under Art. 32 challenging constitutional validity of s. 148-B as violating Art. 26(b) dismissed; held no infringement of fundamental right to manage religious affairs.

key_quotes.text: "The administration of its property by a religious denomination has thus been placed on a different footing from the right to manage its own affairs in matter of religion."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "under Art. 26(b), a religious denomination or Organisation enjoys complete autonomy in the matter of deciding as to what rites and ceremonies are essential according to the tenets of the religion"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "to treat these as matters of religion is tantamount to confusing religion with current politics."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects equating election method with religion

key_quotes.text: "the petitioners have failed to make out a case of violation of their fundamental right."
key_quotes.speaker: court
